critique: This patient should be ventilated in the prone position (Option D). In patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) low tidal volume ventilation (4-8 mL/kg ideal body weight) is recommended. Few other adjunctive therapies have demonstrated additional improved outcomes beyond low tidal volume ventilation. The PROSEVA trial evaluated patients with ARDS who had an arterial Po2/Fio2 ratio of less than 150 mm Hg despite ventilator support. Patients were randomized to conventional therapy or low tidal volume ventilation plus prone positioning within 36 hours of developing ARDS. The results suggested a 16.2% reduction in 28-day all-cause mortality in the prone-position group. The 2017 American Thoracic Society (ATS), European Society of Intensive Care Medicine (ESICM), and Society of Critical Care Medicine (SCCM) guideline, which was updated in 2023 by the ESICM, recommends the early initiation of prone positioning after intubation in patients with ARDS who are being treated with invasive mechanical ventilation if the arterial Po2/Fio2 ratio is less than 150 mm Hg despite optimized ventilator settings. Prone positioning sessions should be prolonged (at least 16 consecutive hours) to reduce mortality.Recruitment (Option A) is the application of a high level of continuous positive airway pressure to open up collapsed alveoli. The 2023 ESICM guideline recommends against high-pressure recruitment maneuvers (airway pressure â‰¥35 cm H2O) regardless of duration to reduce mortality from ARDS. Thus, recruitment would not be an appropriate treatment strategy in this patient.Nitric oxide (NO) (Option B) selectively dilates the pulmonary vasculature when inhaled and may improve ventilation-perfusion mismatch. However, studies of inhaled NO in patients with severe ARDS have demonstrated improvement in oxygenation but no improvement in survival. Thus, it would not be the preferred treatment option in this patient.In 2013, two large, prospective randomized trials demonstrated that, compared with low tidal volume ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option C) was no different or harmful to patients with ARDS. As a result, the ATS/ESICM/SCCM guideline strongly recommends against routine use of high-frequency oscillatory ventilation, and it should be avoided in this patient.
educational_objective: Treat a patient with severe acute respiratory distress syndrome using early prone positioning.
key_points: Both low tidal volume ventilation and prone positioning demonstrate a mortality benefit in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome.

question_stem: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
question_text: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for acute respiratory distress syndrome. He was initially hospitalized for pneumonia. Overnight, he developed fever and increasing respiratory distress and was intubated. Ventilator settings are in the volume-controlled continuous mandatory ventilation mode with low tidal volume ventilation, a positive end-expiratory pressure of 16 cm H2O, and an Fio2 of 1.0. Medications are fentanyl, midazolam, heparin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and norepinephrine.Chest radiograph shows diffuse, bilateral infiltrates throughout the lung fields.
